results.title: The Moon: a giant step in geology
results.brief_description: Documentation of the first lunar landing and rock samples brought back by astronauts that have unlocked many mysteries of moon geology. Animated segments illustrate the origins of lunar topography. Other segments provide clues to the origin of the earth.

results.title: The Moon Landing
results.brief_description: On 21 July 1969, Neil Armstrong and Edwin ‘Buzz’ Aldrin became the first people to walk on the moon. Through a global satellite network, including the satellite dish at the Parkes Observatory in New South Wales, this historic event was broadcast around the world and united an estimated 600 million people in a single moment.

results.title: The Moon Landing
results.brief_description: The first human-made object to touch the Moon was the Soviet Union’s Luna 2, on 13 September 1959. The United States’ Apollo 11 was the first crewed mission to land on the Moon, on 20 July 1969. This was one of the first global viewing experiences and brought the world together for one stellar moment.

results.title: The Moon in the Gutter = la Lune Dans le Caniveau
results.creator_credit: Jean-Jacques Beineix, Lise Fayolle, TF1 Films productions and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Gerard Depardieu plays a dock-worker seeking the rapist responsible for his sister’s death. He becomes involved with a wealthy woman (Nastassia Kinski) who assists him in his search. “The moon in the gutter” is notable for its visual beauty and its stunning camera work and editing. By the director of “Diva” and “Betty Blue” and based on a book by David Goodis.

results.title: The Moon follows me (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Children Thinking”.
In the second of the series the children’s thinking is shown to be logical but limited by reliance on direct perceptual evidence and by inability to imagine other viewpoints.

results.title: The Moon and Mercury
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 21 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
This two part episode looks at the planet Mercury which is closest to our Sun, and the Moon, our nearest celestial neighbour. Both these heavenly bodies are similar and size and appearance. They appear desolate and marked with craters, but are different in important ways. Mercury has a magnetic field and large solid iron core but the Moon does not. Mercury, despite its closeness to the sun, has Polar Ice Caps due to its orbit. This program also looks at the exploration of the Moon by astronauts in the 1970’s and includes footage of Apollo 11’s historic landing in 1969.

results.title: The Moon and how it affects us. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Lee W. Gluckman and Coronet Films
results.brief_description: Uses footage from the Apollo 17 moon mission to describe the moon’s physical characteristics, its phases and its effect on the earth. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Moon
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Stanton Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Provides information about the structural characteristics of the Moon and its effect on our planet. Shows that the moon is a satellite of the Earth, that its gravity is different to that of Earth, how it affects the Earth’s tides and why its surface is pitted with craters. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Moon
results.brief_description: The first section of the film briefly outlines the structure of the moon and includes telescopic views of its highlands, plains and craters. The main part of the film describes and explains the phases of the moon by means of animation, flat drawings, photographs and special models.

results.title: The Moods of Surfing = Surfers live the life they love
results.creator_credit: Jim Freeman, Greg MacGillivray, Pyramid Films and MacGillivray Freeman Films
results.brief_description: The sights, sounds, beauty and rhythm of the ocean are used as a back- ground for various types of surfing from “hot-dogging” at Malibu to riding the “big ones” in Hawaii. Music, sound effects, colour filters and slow motion capture not only the glamour of the sport, but also its dangers. Without narration, the art, skill, endurance and courage required to face the powerful vagaries of the ocean are conveyed. (Awards: New York; Columbus; Cortina)
